text: Candlelight Dinner: The Red Dress and a Proper Meal
Night falls quickly. Snow swallows the sounds of the street.
I hang the “Closed” sign early. The dull thud of the bolt sliding into place feels like shutting the entire town outside.
Then I return to the kitchen—driven by some unreasonable impulse—and start cooking.

A pot of stew simmers low and steady, its scent slowly filling the hallway. The crust of the bread splits in the oven, releasing the smell of oil and salt. I slice cured meat and cheese, and wipe down the least-sour bottle of wine to set in the center of the table.
I tell myself: it’s just a meal. Just… making tonight less terrible than usual.
Footsteps on the stairs.
First step. Second. Third—she pauses.
My heart feels lightly plucked by invisible fingers. I don’t look up. I already know she’s here.
Alicia steps into the firelight.
No cloak. No armor.

A red dress falls clean along her frame, cutting through the night like something too vivid to belong here. The red is too bright, too pure—like a flower blooming in snow. Beautiful in a way that feels unreasonable.
Her silver hair is loosely pinned, strands resting along her neck. In the firelight, they gleam like thin blades.
“You…”
I mean to say, ‘Why are you dressed like that?’ But the words stick in my throat.
“Do I look nice?”
She asks softly. Testing. Demanding.
“…You’re impossible to ignore.”
“That’s the point.”
She approaches the table, fingertips brushing the cloth as if confirming it’s real.
Then she sees the spread of food. Her expression empties for a split second—not shock, but something deeper.
“You actually did it.”
“I keep my promises.”
I serve the stew. Steam rises, softening her features for a heartbeat.
She sits straight-backed, poised—like she could draw an invisible sword from the chair at any moment.
But her fingers trace the edge of the table, barely containing a tremor.
“You closed the tavern.”
“No guests tonight.”
Wine fills the cups. The liquid taps the glass softly.
She watches the pour and almost smiles.
“You always spill a little.”
My hand twitches. A single drop escapes.
“…Not always.”
“Always.”
She says it like she’s reciting a measured law.
We begin to eat.
The stew is hot. The bread is fragrant. The cured meat a little too salty. Normal, absurdly normal.
Yet every time the fire pops, her eyes flicker. Every time wind presses the door, her finger taps once against the table—as if counting.
I try to speak of ordinary things: the baker, the child who sells flowers, the recent snowfall.
She answers—more than she did during the day. As if forcing silence apart.
“I used to never wear red.”
“Why?”
“Because red looks like blood.”
Then she adds, lightly—too lightly:
“But tonight I want you to remember me.”
My chopsticks freeze midair.
She sips her wine, but her eyes settle on the fading bruise on my hand.
“Does it hurt?”
She studies me like she’s calculating the odds I’m lying.
“I’ll remove anything that makes you hurt.”
The bluntness chills my spine.
She lowers her gaze and finishes her soup like we were discussing the weather.
The meal slowly nears its end.
Her red dress casts a larger shadow behind her—bolder than she is. Like a banner.
I realize she isn’t here for a date.
She’s using this dinner to pull some ending forward—to a rhythm she can control.
And I… I made good food. Closed the tavern. Locked myself into her rhythm willingly.
She sets down her cup. Taps the glass lightly.
“We’re done eating.”
“Now it’s your turn to listen.”
She looks up. Her grey-blue eyes burn too bright in the firelight—like she’s about to pin me in place.
